title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: mimicsurv package provides tools survival analysis published Kaplan-Meier tables using person-years method. vignette demonstrates basic usage package functions comprehensive theoretical foundation.

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: main function extractfromKM() estimates hazard rates median survival time published Kaplan-Meier data:
code: # Example data from a hypothetical study time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) n_risk <- c(200, 150, 100, 60, 35) n_censored <- c(0, 10, 20, 30, 40)  # Extract survival analysis results result <- extractfromKM(time_points, n_risk, n_censored)  # View hazard table print(result$hazard_table) #>   interval n_at_risk_start n_censored_interval n_events hazard_rate #> 1    [0,6)             200                  10       40  0.03809524 #> 2   [6,12)             150                  10       40  0.05333333 #> 3  [12,18)             100                  10       30  0.06250000 #> 4  [18,24)              60                  10       15  0.05263158  # View median survival time cat("Median survival time:", result$median_survival, "months\n") #> Median survival time: 14.31321 months

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: hazard table shows: interval: Time intervals hazard estimation n_at_risk_start: Number patients risk start interval n_censored_interval: Number patients censored within interval n_events: Number events (estimated) within interval hazard_rate: Estimated hazard rate (events per person-time)

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: mimicsurv package implements person-years method hazard estimation based several key epidemiological statistical principles. Understanding foundations crucial proper interpretation results.

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: method relies following critical assumptions:

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Within time interval [ti,ti+1)[t_i, t_{+1}), hazard rate Î»i\lambda_i constant. implies survival function within interval ii follows: S(t|tâˆˆ[ti,ti+1))=S(ti)exp(âˆ’Î»i(tâˆ’ti))S(t | t \[t_i, t_{+1})) = S(t_i) \exp(-\lambda_i (t - t_i))

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Censoring independent event process. Formally, TT event time CC censoring time, TâŠ¥CT \perp C. ensures censored observations provide unbiased information risk set.

what: 3. Uniform Distribution of Events and Censoring Within Intervals
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: key assumption person-time calculation. assume events censoring occur uniformly (equal probability) point within interval. Mathematically, event occurs interval [ti,ti+1)[t_i, t_{+1}), time TT follows: T|Tâˆˆ[ti,ti+1)âˆ¼Uniform(ti,ti+1)T | T \[t_i, t_{+1}) \sim \text{Uniform}(t_i, t_{+1}) Consequence: assumption, expected observation time individual experiencing event censoring within interval : E[Tâˆ’ti|Tâˆˆ[ti,ti+1)]=ti+1âˆ’ti2=Î”t2E[T - t_i | T \[t_i, t_{+1})] = \frac{t_{+1} - t_i}{2} = \frac{\Delta t}{2}

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Individuals survive entire interval without events censoring contribute full interval length observation time.

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Person-time represents total observation time contributed individuals. calculation accounts different contribution patterns:

previous_headings: Mathematical Background > Person-Time Calculation: Theoretical Foundation
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Individuals neither experience events censored within interval [ti,ti+1)[t_i, t_{+1}) contribute: - Count: ncomplete=nrisk,+1n_{\text{complete}} = n_{\text{risk},+1} - Time per person: Î”t=ti+1âˆ’ti\Delta t = t_{+1} - t_i - Total contribution: ncompleteÃ—Î”tn_{\text{complete}} \times \Delta t

previous_headings: Mathematical Background > Person-Time Calculation: Theoretical Foundation
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Individuals experiencing events censoring within interval contribute: - Count: npartial=nevents+ncensored=nrisk,âˆ’nrisk,+1n_{\text{partial}} = n_{\text{events}} + n_{\text{censored}} = n_{\text{risk},} - n_{\text{risk},+1} - Expected time per person: Î”t2\frac{\Delta t}{2} (due uniform distribution assumption) - Total contribution: npartialÃ—Î”t2n_{\text{partial}} \times \frac{\Delta t}{2}

previous_headings: Mathematical Background > Person-Time Calculation: Theoretical Foundation
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: uniform distribution assumption, Uâˆ¼Uniform(0,Î”t)U \sim \text{Uniform}(0, \Delta t) represents time interval start event/censoring, : E[U]=0+Î”t2=Î”t2E[U] = \frac{0 + \Delta t}{2} = \frac{\Delta t}{2} multiply Î”t2\frac{\Delta t}{2} rather fraction.

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Combining contributor types: Person-timei=ncompleteÃ—Î”t+npartialÃ—Î”t2\text{Person-time}_i = n_{\text{complete}} \times \Delta t + n_{\text{partial}} \times \frac{\Delta t}{2} Substituting definitions: Person-timei=nrisk,+1Ã—Î”t+(nrisk,âˆ’nrisk,+1)Ã—Î”t2\text{Person-time}_i = n_{\text{risk},+1} \times \Delta t + (n_{\text{risk},} - n_{\text{risk},+1}) \times \frac{\Delta t}{2}

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: formula mathematically equivalent commonly used trapezoidal rule. Algebraic proof: nrisk,+1Ã—Î”t+(nrisk,âˆ’nrisk,+1)Ã—Î”t2n_{\text{risk},+1} \times \Delta t + (n_{\text{risk},} - n_{\text{risk},+1}) \times \frac{\Delta t}{2} =nrisk,+1Ã—Î”t+nrisk,Ã—Î”t2âˆ’nrisk,+1Ã—Î”t2= n_{\text{risk},+1} \times \Delta t + n_{\text{risk},} \times \frac{\Delta t}{2} - n_{\text{risk},+1} \times \frac{\Delta t}{2} =nrisk,+1Ã—Î”t2+nrisk,Ã—Î”t2= n_{\text{risk},+1} \times \frac{\Delta t}{2} + n_{\text{risk},} \times \frac{\Delta t}{2} =nrisk,+nrisk,+12Ã—Î”t= \frac{n_{\text{risk},} + n_{\text{risk},+1}}{2} \times \Delta t Important insight: trapezoidal rule just mathematical convenienceâ€”solid epidemiological foundation based uniform distribution assumption.

what: When the Uniform Distribution Assumption May Fail
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: uniform distribution assumption may violated : Systematic bias event timing: Events tend cluster specific times within intervals Informative censoring patterns: Censoring becomes likely events become likely long intervals: constant hazard assumption becomes less plausible extended periods cases, alternative approaches (e.g., shorter intervals, different distributional assumptions) may necessary.

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: piecewise exponential assumption, hazard rate interval ii estimated : Î»Ì‚=Number eventsiPerson-timei\hat{\lambda}_i = \frac{\text{Number events}_i}{\text{Person-time}_i} Statistical Properties: - estimator maximum likelihood estimator exponential distribution assumption - unbiased: E[Î»Ì‚]=Î»iE[\hat{\lambda}_i] = \lambda_i - large samples, follows approximately: Î»Ì‚âˆ¼N(Î»i,Î»i/Person-timei)\hat{\lambda}_i \sim N(\lambda_i, \lambda_i/\text{Person-time}_i)

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: piecewise exponential survival, survival function : S(t)=exp(âˆ’âˆ‘j=1kÎ»jÃ—min(Î”tj,max(0,tâˆ’tjâˆ’1)))S(t) = \exp\left(-\sum_{j=1}^{k} \lambda_j \times \min(\Delta t_j, \max(0, t - t_{j-1}))\right) median survival time t0.5t_{0.5} satisfies S(t0.5)=0.5S(t_{0.5}) = 0.5. interval kk containing median: tmedian=tk+1Î»kln(S(tk)0.5)t_{\text{median}} = t_k + \frac{1}{\lambda_k} \ln\left(\frac{S(t_k)}{0.5}\right) Note: S(tfinal)â‰¥0.5S(t_{\text{final}}) \geq 0.5, median reached within observation period.

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Using study data, letâ€™s trace calculations:
code:
# Our study data time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) n_risk <- c(200, 150, 100, 60, 35) n_censored <- c(0, 10, 20, 30, 40)  # Calculate for first interval [0,6) interval_1 <- list(   n_at_start = 200,   n_at_end = 150,   n_censored_in_interval = 10 - 0,  # 10   n_events_in_interval = 200 - 150 - 10,  # 40   interval_length = 6 - 0  # 6 )  # Person-time calculation person_time_1 <- interval_1$n_at_end * interval_1$interval_length +                   (interval_1$n_events_in_interval + interval_1$n_censored_in_interval) *                   interval_1$interval_length / 2  cat("Interval [0,6):
") #> Interval [0,6): cat("- Complete observation:", interval_1$n_at_end, "persons Ã—", interval_1$interval_length, "months =",      interval_1$n_at_end * interval_1$interval_length, "person-months
") #> - Complete observation: 150 persons Ã— 6 months = 900 person-months cat("- Partial observation:", interval_1$n_events_in_interval + interval_1$n_censored_in_interval,      "persons Ã—", interval_1$interval_length/2, "months =",      (interval_1$n_events_in_interval + interval_1$n_censored_in_interval) * interval_1$interval_length/2, "person-months
") #> - Partial observation: 50 persons Ã— 3 months = 150 person-months cat("- Total person-time:", person_time_1, "person-months
") #> - Total person-time: 1050 person-months  # Hazard rate calculation hazard_rate_1 <- interval_1$n_events_in_interval / person_time_1 cat("- Hazard rate:", interval_1$n_events_in_interval, "events /", person_time_1,      "person-months =", round(hazard_rate_1, 6), "per month
") #> - Hazard rate: 40 events / 1050 person-months = 0.038095 per month

previous_headings: Mathematical Background > Assumptions in Practice: Critical Considerations
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: often questionable assumption. reality: - Early events: conditions higher risk immediately exposure - Late events: Progressive diseases may show increasing risk time - Periodic patterns: events follow circadian seasonal patterns Sensitivity analysis: Consider varying interval lengths using alternative assumptions seems implausible.

previous_headings: Mathematical Background > Assumptions in Practice: Critical Considerations
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: assumption reasonable : - Intervals relatively short (e.g., 3-6 months chronic diseases) - underlying biological process constant risk - major time-varying confounders within intervals

previous_headings: Mathematical Background > Assumptions in Practice: Critical Considerations
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: may violated : - Patients withdraw due disease progression - Loss follow-related prognosis - Administrative censoring correlates risk factors

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Now letâ€™s work backwards - starting estimated hazard rates, can simulate data validate method:
code:
# Use the hazard rates estimated from our KM table estimated_hazards <- result$hazard_table$hazard_rate cat("Estimated hazard rates:", paste(round(estimated_hazards, 4), collapse = ", "), "
") #> Estimated hazard rates: 0.0381, 0.0533, 0.0625, 0.0526  # Simulate data using these estimated parameters set.seed(123)  # For reproducible results sim_data <- simPE(   n = 200,  # Same initial sample size as our study   time_points = time_points,   hazard_rates = estimated_hazards,   max_time = 24,   censoring_prob = 0.1 )  # Check the simulated data cat("Simulated data summary:
") #> Simulated data summary: cat("- Total subjects:", nrow(sim_data), "
") #> - Total subjects: 200 cat("- Events:", sum(sim_data$status == 1), "
")  #> - Events: 140 cat("- Censored:", sum(sim_data$status == 0), "
") #> - Censored: 60 cat("- Event rate:", round(mean(sim_data$status), 2), "
") #> - Event rate: 0.7

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Letâ€™s create KM-style summary simulated data compare original:
code:
# Create KM table from simulated data km_summary <- summaryKM(sim_data, time_points)  cat("Comparison of original vs simulated data:
") #> Comparison of original vs simulated data: comparison_table <- data.frame(   Time = time_points,   Original_N_Risk = c(200, 150, 100, 60, 35),   Simulated_N_Risk = km_summary$n_risk,   Original_N_Censored = c(0, 10, 20, 30, 40),   Simulated_N_Censored = km_summary$n_censored_cumulative ) print(comparison_table) #>   Time Original_N_Risk Simulated_N_Risk Original_N_Censored #> 1    0             200              200                   0 #> 2    6             150              200                  10 #> 3   12             100              199                  20 #> 4   18              60              199                  30 #> 5   24              35              174                  40 #>   Simulated_N_Censored #> 1                    0 #> 2                    0 #> 3                    1 #> 4                    1 #> 5                   60  # Re-estimate hazard rates from simulated data sim_result <- extractfromKM(   time_points = time_points,   n_risk = km_summary$n_risk,   n_censored = km_summary$n_censored_cumulative ) #> Warning in extractfromKM(time_points = time_points, n_risk = km_summary$n_risk, #> : Negative events detected in some intervals. Setting to 0.  cat("
Hazard rate comparison:
") #>  #> Hazard rate comparison: hazard_comparison <- data.frame(   Interval = result$hazard_table$interval,   Original_Hazard = result$hazard_table$hazard_rate,   Simulated_Hazard = sim_result$hazard_table$hazard_rate,   Relative_Error = abs(sim_result$hazard_table$hazard_rate - result$hazard_table$hazard_rate) /                     result$hazard_table$hazard_rate * 100 ) print(hazard_comparison) #>   Interval Original_Hazard Simulated_Hazard Relative_Error #> 1    [0,6)      0.03809524                0            100 #> 2   [6,12)      0.05333333                0            100 #> 3  [12,18)      0.06250000                0            100 #> 4  [18,24)      0.05263158                0            100

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: validate_mimicsurv() function provides comprehensive validation hazard estimation methods:
code: # Run validation study (small example for demonstration) validation_result <- validate_mimicsurv(   true_time_points = time_points,   true_hazard_rates = estimated_hazards,   sample_sizes = c(100, 200),   n_simulations = 50,   censoring_prob = 0.15 )  # View summary statistics print(validation_result$summary_statistics)  # View detailed results for one sample size print(validation_result$detailed_results$n_200$hazard_results)

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: â€™s practical example showing well method recovers known parameters:
code:
# Set known "true" parameters similar to our study true_times <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) true_hazards <- c(0.038, 0.053, 0.063, 0.053)  # Similar to our estimated rates  # Calculate true median survival true_median <- getMediansurv(true_times, true_hazards) cat("True median survival:", round(true_median, 1), "months
") #> True median survival: 14.3 months  # Simulate larger dataset for better precision set.seed(456) large_sim_data <- simPE(   n = 1000,  # Larger sample for better precision   time_points = true_times,   hazard_rates = true_hazards,   max_time = 24,   censoring_prob = 0.15 )  # Create KM table from simulated data large_km_table <- summaryKM(large_sim_data, true_times)  # Estimate parameters from the KM table estimated_result <- extractfromKM(   time_points = true_times,   n_risk = large_km_table$n_risk,   n_censored = large_km_table$n_censored_cumulative ) #> Warning in extractfromKM(time_points = true_times, n_risk = #> large_km_table$n_risk, : Negative events detected in some intervals. Setting to #> 0.  # Compare results cat("
Validation Results (n=1000):
") #>  #> Validation Results (n=1000): validation_comparison <- data.frame(   Interval = estimated_result$hazard_table$interval,   True_Hazard = true_hazards,   Estimated_Hazard = estimated_result$hazard_table$hazard_rate,   Relative_Error = abs(estimated_result$hazard_table$hazard_rate - true_hazards) / true_hazards * 100 ) print(validation_comparison) #>   Interval True_Hazard Estimated_Hazard Relative_Error #> 1    [0,6)       0.038                0            100 #> 2   [6,12)       0.053                0            100 #> 3  [12,18)       0.063                0            100 #> 4  [18,24)       0.053                0            100  cat("
Median Survival Comparison:
") #>  #> Median Survival Comparison: cat("True median:", round(true_median, 1), "months
") #> True median: 14.3 months cat("Estimated median:", round(estimated_result$median_survival, 1), "months
") #> Estimated median: NA months if (!is.na(estimated_result$median_survival)) {   relative_error <- abs(estimated_result$median_survival - true_median) / true_median * 100   cat("Relative error:", round(relative_error, 1), "%
") }

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: can calculate theoretical median survival time directly:
code: # Calculate true median for comparison using our estimated hazards true_median <- getMediansurv(time_points, estimated_hazards) cat("Theoretical median survival:", round(true_median, 2), "months\n") #> Theoretical median survival: 14.31 months

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: package handles various scenarios: High censoring rates: Appropriate studies substantial loss follow-Multiple intervals: Flexible number time intervals Missing median: Returns NA median survival reached Edge cases: Robust handling boundary conditions

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Data Quality: Ensure input data consistent (number risk decrease time) Interval Selection: Use meaningful time intervals reflect clinical practice Assumption Checking: Verify uniform distribution assumption reasonable Validation: Use simulation studies validate results possible Interpretation: Consider assumptions piecewise exponential survival Sensitivity Analysis: Test robustness different interval definitions

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: mimicsurv package provides comprehensive framework extracting survival information published Kaplan-Meier data. combination : Rigorous theoretical foundation clear assumptions Robust estimation methods based maximum likelihood principles Comprehensive validation tools method verification Practical examples demonstrating real-world applications makes valuable tool meta-analyses secondary data analyses survival research. person-years method, based specific assumptions, provides statistically sound approach extracting quantitative information published survival curves individual patient data available.

title: mimicsurv
text: R package survival analysis Kaplan-Meier tables using person-years method.

title: mimicsurv
text: mimicsurv package provides functions estimate hazard rates median survival time published Kaplan-Meier table data using person-years method, assuming exponential distribution within interval. also includes simulation functions validation estimation methods.

title: mimicsurv
text: ðŸ“– Getting Started mimicsurv - Complete tutorial examples

title: mimicsurv
text: ðŸ“š Package Reference - Detailed function documentation

title: mimicsurv
text: can install development version mimicsurv GitHub:
code: # Install devtools if you haven't already install.packages("devtools")  # Install mimicsurv from GitHub devtools::install_github("gosukehommaEX/mimicsurv")

title: mimicsurv
text: package requires following R packages: - stats (base R) - utils (base R) - PWEALL (simulation validation)

title: mimicsurv
text: extractfromKM(): Extract survival analysis results Kaplan-Meier table using person-years method getMediansurv(): Calculate median survival time piecewise exponential parameters

title: mimicsurv
text: simPE(): Simulate survival data piecewise exponential distribution summaryKM(): Create Kaplan-Meier style summary table simulated data validate_mimicsurv(): Comprehensive simulation study hazard estimation validation

title: mimicsurv
code: library(mimicsurv)  # Example: Basic survival analysis from KM table time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) n_risk <- c(200, 150, 100, 60, 35) n_censored <- c(0, 10, 20, 30, 40)  result <- extractfromKM(time_points, n_risk, n_censored) print(result$hazard_table) print(paste("Median survival:", result$median_survival, "months"))  # Example: Simulation validation true_times <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) true_hazards <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  validation_result <- validate_mimicsurv(   true_time_points = true_times,   true_hazard_rates = true_hazards,   sample_sizes = c(100, 200),   n_simulations = 50,   censoring_prob = 0.15 )  print(validation_result$summary_statistics)

title: mimicsurv
text: package implements survival analysis methods based : Person-years method: Calculates hazard rates events per person-time using trapezoidal rule Piecewise exponential model: Assumes constant hazard within intervals Median survival estimation: Uses exponential survival function: S(t) = exp(-âˆ‘Î»â±¼Î”tâ±¼)

title: mimicsurv
text: Gosuke Homma GitHub: gosukehommaEX

what: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method â€” extractfromKM
title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method â€” extractfromKM
text: function estimates hazard rates median survival time published Kaplan-Meier table data using person-years method, assuming exponential distribution within interval.

title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method â€” extractfromKM
code: extractfromKM(time_points, n_risk, n_censored, warn_negative_events = TRUE)

title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method â€” extractfromKM
text: time_points Numeric vector time points (length n+1 n intervals) n_risk Numeric vector number risk time point (length n+1) n_censored Numeric vector cumulative number censored time point (length n+1) warn_negative_events Logical, whether warn negative events (default TRUE)

title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method â€” extractfromKM
text: List containing: hazard_table Data frame interval summaries hazard rates median_survival Estimated median survival time (NA reached)

title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method â€” extractfromKM
text: function calculates: Number events interval (accounting risk set changes) Person-time using trapezoidal rule Hazard rates events/person-time Median survival time using exponential survival function

title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method â€” extractfromKM
code: # Example 1: Basic usage time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) n_risk <- c(200, 165, 130, 95, 65) n_censored <- c(0, 15, 35, 53, 65)  result <- extractfromKM(time_points, n_risk, n_censored) print(result$hazard_table) #>   interval n_at_risk_start n_censored_interval n_events hazard_rate #> 1    [0,6)             200                  15       20  0.01826484 #> 2   [6,12)             165                  20       15  0.01694915 #> 3  [12,18)             130                  18       17  0.02518519 #> 4  [18,24)              95                  12       18  0.03750000 print(paste("Median survival:", result$median_survival, "months")) #> [1] "Median survival: NA months"

what: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters â€” getMediansurv
title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters â€” getMediansurv
text: function calculates median survival time time points hazard rates using piecewise exponential survival function.

title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters â€” getMediansurv
code: getMediansurv(time_points, hazard_rates)

title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters â€” getMediansurv
text: time_points Numeric vector time points defining intervals hazard_rates Numeric vector hazard rates interval

title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters â€” getMediansurv
text: Numeric scalar median survival time (NA reached)

title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters â€” getMediansurv
text: function assumes piecewise exponential survival constant hazard within interval. calculates survival probabilities time point finds time survival probability equals 0.5. Mathematical formulation: $$S(t) = \exp\left(-\sum_{j=1}^{k} \lambda_j \cdot \Delta t_j\right)$$ \(\lambda_j\) hazard rate interval j \(\Delta t_j\) length interval j time t.

title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters â€” getMediansurv
code: # Calculate median for 4-interval model time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) hazard_rates <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  median_time <- getMediansurv(time_points, hazard_rates) print(paste("Median survival:", round(median_time, 2), "months")) #> [1] "Median survival: 10.91 months"

what: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution â€” simPE
title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution â€” simPE
text: function generates simulated survival data following piecewise exponential distribution specified time intervals hazard rates.

title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution â€” simPE
code: simPE(n, time_points, hazard_rates, max_time, censoring_prob = 0.1)

title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution â€” simPE
text: n Sample size (number subjects simulate) time_points Numeric vector time points defining intervals hazard_rates Numeric vector hazard rates interval max_time Maximum follow-time (administrative censoring) censoring_prob Probability random censoring (default 0.1)

title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution â€” simPE
text: Data frame columns: time Observed time (either event time censoring time) status Event indicator (1 = event, 0 = censored)

title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution â€” simPE
text: function simulates survival times using inverse transform sampling piecewise exponential distribution. Random censoring applied uniformly 0 simulated survival time.

title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution â€” simPE
code: # Simulate data with 4 intervals time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) hazard_rates <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  sim_data <- simPE(   n = 200,   time_points = time_points,   hazard_rates = hazard_rates,   max_time = 24,   censoring_prob = 0.15 )  # Check event rate table(sim_data$status) #>  #>   0   1  #>  25 175

what: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data â€” summaryKM
title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data â€” summaryKM
text: function creates summary table Kaplan-Meier format simulated individual patient data, calculating number risk cumulative censoring specified time points.

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data â€” summaryKM
code: summaryKM(sim_data, time_points)

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data â€” summaryKM
text: sim_data Data frame time status columns simulation time_points Time points summary table creation

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data â€” summaryKM
text: List containing: n_risk Numeric vector number risk time point n_censored_cumulative Numeric vector cumulative censored time point

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data â€” summaryKM
text: function processes individual patient data create aggregate summaries mimic published Kaplan-Meier tables. Number risk represents patients yet experienced event censored time point.

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data â€” summaryKM
code: # First simulate data time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) hazard_rates <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  sim_data <- simPE(   n = 200,   time_points = time_points,   hazard_rates = hazard_rates,   max_time = 24 )  # Create KM table km_summary <- summaryKM(sim_data, time_points) print(km_summary$n_risk) #> [1] 200 199 199 197 169 print(km_summary$n_censored_cumulative) #> [1]  0  1  1  3 17

what: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation â€” validate_mimicsurv
title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation â€” validate_mimicsurv
text: function conducts comprehensive simulation study validate performance hazard estimation methods using person-years approach implemented mimicsurv package.

title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation â€” validate_mimicsurv
code: validate_mimicsurv(   true_time_points,   true_hazard_rates,   sample_sizes = c(100, 200, 500),   n_simulations = 100,   max_followup = NULL,   censoring_prob = 0.1,   use_pweall = FALSE )

title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation â€” validate_mimicsurv
text: true_time_points Time points defining intervals simulation true_hazard_rates True hazard rates interval sample_sizes Vector sample sizes test (default: c(100, 200, 500)) n_simulations Number simulation replications (default: 100) max_followup Maximum follow-time (default: max time_points) censoring_prob Probability random censoring (default: 0.1) use_pweall Logical, whether use PWEALL package available (default: FALSE)

title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation â€” validate_mimicsurv
text: List containing: simulation_parameters Input parameters true values detailed_results Detailed results sample size summary_statistics Summary statistics across sample sizes

title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation â€” validate_mimicsurv
text: function performs following steps sample size: Generate simulated data piecewise exponential distribution Create Kaplan-Meier style summary tables Apply hazard estimation method Calculate bias, MSE, coverage statistics Summarize performance across replications Performance metrics include: Bias: Mean difference estimated true values MSE: Mean squared error Coverage: Proportion estimates within acceptable range Convergence rate: Proportion successful estimations

title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation â€” validate_mimicsurv
code: # Small simulation study true_times <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) true_hazards <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  validation_result <- validate_mimicsurv(   true_time_points = true_times,   true_hazard_rates = true_hazards,   sample_sizes = c(100, 200),   n_simulations = 50,   censoring_prob = 0.15 ) #> Running simulations for sample size 100... #> Running simulations for sample size 200...  # View summary statistics print(validation_result$summary_statistics) #>       sample_size convergence_rate median_bias median_mse #> n_100         100                1          NA         NA #> n_200         200                1          NA         NA

title: mimicsurv 0.1.0
text: Initial release mimicsurv package extractfromKM(): Extract survival analysis results Kaplan-Meier tables using person-years method getMediansurv(): Calculate median survival time piecewise exponential parameters simPE(): Simulate survival data piecewise exponential distribution summaryKM(): Create Kaplan-Meier style summary tables simulated data validate_mimicsurv(): Comprehensive simulation study hazard estimation validation Integration PWEALL package enhanced simulation capabilities

title: mimicsurv 0.1.0
text: Person-years method hazard rate estimation Piecewise exponential survival model Trapezoidal rule person-time calculation Inverse transform sampling simulation

title: mimicsurv 0.1.0
text: Complete roxygen2 documentation functions Mathematical formulations using LaTeX notation Comprehensive examples usage guidelines
